variant.question: A vertical speed indicator measures the difference between:

a large rate of change is displayed more accurately than a small rate of change

The autopilot switches automatically to the outputs provided by the direct reading compass.

When engaged, the autopilot manoeuvres the aeroplane in accordance within a set of control laws. The purpose of these control laws is to...

options.text: prevent unacceptable loads on the aeroplane or prevent hazardous deviations from the flight path.
ensure any movement of the control surface(s) is smooth and accurate for improved passenger comfort.
prevent the ability to by-pass the computers or the standby systems to operate without the computers.
prevent the aeroplane from deviating from its desired flight path by an amount exceeding the limits established by the operator.

variant.question: The principal function of the synchroniser circuit in an autopilot pitch channel is to:

options.text: Ensure a smooth transition in pitch after switching on the autopilot.
Synchronise aircraft heading with the GPS heading.
Ensure that the power settings of the autothrust synchronises with the aircraft pitch.
Synchronise aircraft attitude with the altitude.

variant.question: You are the Pilot Flying (PF) and just about to approach your destination. The autopilot is engaged, and as you reduce speed in accordance with your clearance you instinctively trim up significantly on the pitch trim wheel, reverting to the aircraft type you trained on, which had NO auto-trim. The consequence may be:

options.text: An out-of-trim condition, which may cause the autopilot to disconnect and the aircraft to pitch up.
That the autopilot may be unable to counteract your trim input quickly enough. The aircraft may pitch down, requiring you to disconnect the autopilot and fly manually.
That the moment you move the trim wheel the autopilot will disconnect. The aircraft will be perfectly in trim, and you will be able to re-engage the autopilot WITHOUT re-trimming.

That the autopilot will fly the rest of the approach with an out-of-trim load, which may leave insufficient authority should a go-around be necessary. This is corrected by disengaging and re-engaging the autopilot.

variant.question:
How can the control law of an autopilot control channel be defined as? 
 The relationship between the:

options.text: Computer input deviation data and the output control deflection signals.
Computer input deviation data and the signals received by the servoactuators.
Crew inputs to the computer and the detector responses (returned to the airplane).
Input and output signals at the amplifier level respectively control deviation data and control deflection signals.

variant.question:
The automatic synchronisation function of an autopilot control system:
1) operates only when the autopilot is engaged.

3) prevents the aircraft's control system from jerking when engaging the autopilot.
4) works in approach, heading & nav mode.
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:

options.text: 1 only

is damped by a trim input signal from the lateral trim system.
remains always coupled to the selected VOR radial.
is temporarily disconnected.

options.text: temporary manual flying while the autopilot is still engaged.
assist the flare during the autoland.
disengagement of the autopilot to make a flight path change, before reengaging it back.
steering of the aircraft via a touch screen.

variant.question:
Considering vertical modes of the flight guidance system. What is the appropriate description of the following two vertical modes?
  • Vertical speed (V/S) - Flight-Path Angle (FPA)

options.text: Both modes will make the aeroplane follow a trajectory where V/S uses feet per minute as reference and FPA uses an angle.
V/S will maintain a rate of climb or descent as set by the pilot while FPA will maintain a flight-path angle as coded in the FMS.
V/S will maintain a selected airspeed during the climb or descent and FPA will maintain a selected geometric flight-path angle during climb or descent.
Both modes will make the aeroplane maintain a selected vertical speed, which varies with the airspeed to maintain a constant flight-path angle.

variant.question:
In an autopilot system, the guidance modes are:
1. Pitch angle hold
2. IAS and Mach number hold

options.text: engagement occurs only if the aircraft is in trim, with control loads very low.
trim is mechanically centred, ensuring that the full range of movement is available to the auto-trim system.
a delay of 5 seconds occurs while the autopilot motors the auto-trim up and down, until the trim position has been identified.
a pitch-up trim load is always maintained by the autopilot, ensuring the deviation when the autopilot disconnects is predictable and consistent.

variant.question: How does a Touch Control Steering (TCS) system work?

options.text: By pressing a button to disengage the flight controls from the autopilot.
By using a separate set of flight controls to provide the autopilot with new control inputs.
When the pilot touches the flight controls, the autopilot is automatically disengaged.
By using a touchpad instead of a control stick/wheel to control the aircraft.

Monitoring the movement of the aeroplane centre of gravity.

variant.question: How does the mixed mode work and what inputs does it need?

options.text: In the mixed mode for the vertical path, the autopilot uses a pitch attitude (or pitch attitude rate) which allows to avoid a tail-strike during take off, and for the lateral path, it uses the localizer signal to keep the runway centreline.
The mixed modes are exclusively used for the low visibility take-off and landing.
It works on the same principle as the CWS and reduces the pilot’s workload for flight path management.
The mixed mode uses a constant vertical speed to ensure the obstacle clearance and uses a heading/track mode to keep the centreline of the runway.

with no limit of approach airspeeds.
at VY ± 5 kts only.
at 70 kts ± 5 kts only.

variant.question: The block image of an auto-pilot is shown in the annex. For each control channel (pitch, roll and yaw) the control law is the relationship between the commanded deflection of the control surface by the computer (BETA c) and the

options.text: offset EPSILON at the computer input.
aircraft response S on all three channels.
aircraft response S on the relevant channel.
pilot command E.

variant.question: Which of the following statements correctly describes the vertical speed (V/S) mode and the flight path angle (FPA) mode of an autopilot system?

options.text: The aircraft will follow a trajectory with both modes but they use a different reference. V/S uses feet per minute and FPA uses an angle.
Both modes maintain a selected vertical speed. The corresponding flight path angle depends on the airspeed.
V/S maintains a selected airspeed during the climb and descent, and the FPA maintains a selected geometric flight path angle.
V/S maintains a selected rate of climb or rate of descent, and the FPA maintains a flight path angle based on the FMS.

variant.question:
The lateral flight path modes of an autopilot system are:
1) speed hold.
2) localiser intercept and track.
3) track hold.
4) FMS lateral navigation.
5) pitch attitude hold.
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
During automatic flight, the autopilot...

options.text: directly acts on the servo valves of the control surfaces.
amplifies the pilot inputs to the servo valves of the control surfaces.
instructs the pilot how to act on the servo valves of the control surfaces.
modifies or limits the pilot inputs to the servo valves of the control surfaces.

variant.question:
Which of the following functions of an autopilot are related to the aeroplane stabilisation?
1. Pitch angle hold
2. IAS or Mach number hold
3. Wings level hold
4. VOR radial hold

options.text: 1 and 3 only
2 and 4 only
1, 2 and 3
1, 3 and 4

variant.question: In an autopilot system, the flight path modes are: - Pitch attitude hold - IAS and Mach number hold - Altitude hold - Glide slope intercept and track The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:

options.text: 4 only
3 only

variant.question: The control law of a transport airplane autopilot control channel may be defined as the relationship between the:

options.text: computer input deviation data and the output control deflection signals.
input and output signals at the amplifier level respectively control deviation data and control deflection signals.
crew inputs to the computer and the detector responses (returned to the airplane).
computer input deviation data and the signals received by the servo actuators.

variant.question: The CS 25 gives the following definition: Where the pilot has the ability to make inputs to the automatic pilot by movement of the normal control wheel. The corresponding mode is:

options.text: control wheel steering (CWS).
automatic wheel steering (AWS).
nose wheel steering (NWS).
alternate wheel steering (AWS).

variant.question: You are flying an aircraft at FL350 with the autopilot engaged in VNAV and LNAV modes. What are the consequences of an auto-trim failure in these conditions?

options.text: The autopilot will disconnect and the pilot flying should take the controls.
The company should be notified and advice should be seen from MCC.
The abnormal rudder jam checklist should be performed.
An emergency descent should be initiated.

variant.question: When the autopilot is engaged, the role of the automatic pitch trim is to:

options.text: relieve the autopilot servo motor and return the aircraft in-trim when disconnecting the autopilot.
synchronise the longitudinal loop.
block the elevator and pilot the aircraft only via the trim tab actuator or the horizontal stabiliser.
respond to altitude changes in Altitude Hold mode.

variant.question: When using the autopilot, the function of the pitch channel automatic trim is to: - off-load any steady-state elevator deflections. - ease as much as possible the steady-state load of the rudder. - off-load any trim force before autopilot disengagement. The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:

options.text: 1 only

variant.question: The autopilot is engaged in VNAV and LNAV at FL350. What will happen if in the middle of the flight the auto-trim becomes inoperative?

options.text: The autopilot will disconnect and the pilot flying should take the controls.
The company should be notified and advice should be seek from MCC.
The abnormal rudder jam checklist should be performed.
An emergency descent should be initiated.

variant.question:
The purpose of the automatic trim is to:
1) reduce to zero the hinge moment of the entire control surface in order to relieve the load on the servo-actuator.
2) ensure the aeroplane is properly trimmed when the autopilot is disengaged.
3) maintain the same stability/manoeuvrability trade-off within the whole flight envelope.
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
The purpose of auto trim function in autopilot is to:

options.text: control elevator trim tab in order to relieve elevator load.
trim throttles to obtain smooth engine power variation.
tell the pilot when elevator trimming is required.
help autopilot compensate for crosswind influence.

variant.question:
When using the autopilot, the function of the pitch channel automatic trim is (are) to:
1) cancel the hinge moment of the elevator.
2) ease as much as possible the load of the servo-actuator.
3) restore to the pilot a correctly trimmed airplane during the autopilot disengagement.
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:

The computers of the electrical flight controls system comply with programs defined by attitude control laws such as
1) on the longitudinal axis, the law may combine the load factor and the changes in the pitch rate as control data sources.
2) the trimming is automatic and ensures neutral stability.
3) the protections apply to pitch and bank attitudes depending on the speed.
4) these laws do not apply to the whole flight envelope.The combination re-grouping all the

When using the autopilot, the function(s) of the automatic pitch trim is (are) to:
1 – off-load any steady state elevator deflection  
2 – ease the steady state load of the rudder as much as possible  
3 – cancel out of trim force during autopilot disengagement.The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
Auto trim is fitted to an autopilot:

options.text: to prevent snatching on disengaging A/P.
to provide control about lateral axis.
to correct for Mach tuck.
to prevent snatching on engaging A/P.

variant.question: When could a pilot use the auto trim on a non fly-by-wire aeroplane?

options.text: When AP is engaged.
Only during cruise.
When AP is armed.
Always.

variant.question: What is the main purpose of the autothrottle on take-off?

options.text: To set and hold a commanded thrust setting.
To hold a speed once airborne.
To hold an attitude after take off.
To constantly adjust the thrust on the take off roll.

variant.question:
Refer to figure 022-24.
Refer to attached autoflight control panel. What is the function of the switch marked “2”?

options.text: Enabling automatic engagement of autothrottle in specified conditions.
Selection whether speed shall be controlled by autothrottle or autopilot pitch channel.
Display or removal of autothrottle targets on the PFD speed tape.
Engagement and disengagement of autothrottle.

variant.question:
What states can an autothrottle be in?
1) Active.
2) Armed.
3) Disengaged.
Which answer comprises all correct states?

options.text: None of the states listed above.

variant.question:
In order to know in which mode the auto-throttle is engaged, the crew will check the: 1. auto-throttle ARM switches
2. auto-throttle disengage switches
3. autopilot mode control panel
4. mode annunciator panel (FMA)
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
Which function does autothrottle perform during the engine start sequence?

options.text: Autothrottle is not used for engine start.
Autothrottle offers protection against a wet start.
Autothrottle offers protection against a hot start.
Autothrottle considers ambient conditions to ensure optimum engine start.

variant.question: The purpose of the autothrottle is...

options.text: to maintain constant engine power or airplane speed.
automatic shut down of one engine at too high temperature.
to synchronize engines to avoid "yawing".
to deactivate manual throttles and transfer engine control to autopilot.

variant.question: When flying level in the cruise the ___ holds altitude and the ___ holds the speed.

options.text: autopilot; autothrottle
autopilot; autopilot
autothrottle; autothrottle
autothrottle; autopilot

variant.question: A pilot inserts a waypoint EASAG, with reference to HDGB VOR radial 212 and HSBJ VOR radial 265. How do you call this type of entry?

options.text: Place bearing / Place bearing (PBX)
Nav aid bearing / Nav aid place bearing
VOR bearing / VOR bearing
Place bearing distance (PBD)

variant.question:
Which of the following parameters are used by the FMS vertical guidance function?
1) Angle of attack
2) Flight path angle
3) Airspeed
The autopilot uses FMS inputs to automatically fly a flightplan, if...

options.text: a route is selected and activated and NAV mode is active.
a route is selected and activated.
NAV mode is active.
HDG Mode is selected.

variant.question: If crew awareness is required and subsequent crew action may be required, the flight warning system (FWS) generates

options.text: an advisory message.
a call message.
a caution message.
a warning message.

variant.question: What kind of warning you can expect when disconnecting the autopilot for manual flying during the approach?

options.text: Both visual and aural warning.
Only an aural warning.
Only a visual warning.
Both visual and tactile warning.

variant.question: The pilot of a large transport aeroplane equipped with EFIS is flying in the cruise with the autopilot ON. The pilot is completing paperwork and is NOT looking at the control panel when a potentially hazardous situation requires crew attention but NOT immediate action. How is the pilot's attention drawn to the problem?

options.text: A yellow or amber light in the pilot's normal primary field of vision with an aural alert.
A yellow or amber warning on the ECAM panel with NO aural alert.
A red light indicating the nature of the problem with an aural alert.
A red light in the pilot's normal primary field of vision with NO aural alert.

variant.question:
The guidance modes of an autopilot system are:
1) holding pitch angle
2) holding IAS and Mach number
3) holding altitude
4) intercepting and tracking of glide slopes
When an aircraft, operating in the VOR coupled mode, enters the cone of confusion over a VOR station the autopilot

options.text: temporarily maintains existing heading.
remains always coupled to the selected VOR radial.
is damped by a trim input signal from the lateral trim system.
is temporarily disconnected.

variant.question: The pilot`s control input in a Fly-By-Wire system is

options.text: converted into an electrical signal and linked via a computer to the flight control surface.
linked by electrical wires directly to the flight control surface.
linked mechanically to a computer and then to the flight control surface.
linked by mechanical cables directly to the flight control surface.

variant.question: Which autopilot mode is engaged to hold a flight path in the horizontal plane?

options.text: LNAV
PATH
VOR/LOC
FMS
